comment: Principle to a hierarchy of examples: "Meal" comes after Human "lover/partner/mate." Also, the connection between lovers is affection," primarily, "attraction" is not itself a love of another person.

[[File:DickseeRomeoandJuliet.jpg|thumb|Archetypal lovers [[Romeo and Juliet]] portrayed by [[Frank Bernard Dicksee|Frank Dicksee]]]]
−
The English word '''"love"''' can refer to a variety of different feelings, states, and attitudes, ranging from pleasure ("I loved that meal") to [[interpersonal attraction]] ("I love my partner"). It can refer to an [[emotion]] of a strong [[affection]] and personal [[attachment (psychology)|attachment]].<ref name="oxford">''Oxford Illustrated American Dictionary'' (1998) + ''Merriam-Webster Collegiate Dictionary'' (2000)</ref> It can also be a [[virtue]] representing human [[kindness]], [[compassion]], and affection—"the unselfish loyal and benevolent concern for the good of another".<ref>[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/love Merriam Webster Dictionary]</ref> And it may describe compassionate and affectionate actions towards other humans, one's self or animals.<ref name="Fromm, Erich 1956">Fromm, Erich; ''The Art of Loving'', Harper Perennial (1956), Original English Version, ISBN 978-0-06-095828-2</ref>
+
The English word '''"love"''' can refer to a variety of different feelings, states, and attitudes, ranging from interpersonal [[affection]] ("I love my lover") to pleasure ("I loved that meal"). It can refer to an [[emotion]] of a strong [[interpersonal attraction|attraction]] and personal [[attachment (psychology)|attachment]].<ref name="oxford">''Oxford Illustrated American Dictionary'' (1998) + ''Merriam-Webster Collegiate Dictionary'' (2000)</ref> It can also be a [[virtue]] representing human [[kindness]], [[compassion]], and affection—"the unselfish loyal and benevolent concern for the good of another".<ref>[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/love Merriam Webster Dictionary]</ref> And it may describe compassionate and affectionate actions towards other humans, one's self or animals.<ref name="Fromm, Erich 1956">Fromm, Erich; ''The Art of Loving'', Harper Perennial (1956), Original English Version, ISBN 978-0-06-095828-2</ref>
     
In terms of interpersonal attraction, four forms of love have traditionally been distinguished, based on ancient Greek precedent: the love of kinship or [[familial love|familiarity]] (in [[Ancient Greek|Greek]], ''[[storge]]''), the love of [[friendship]] (''[[philia]]''), the love of sexual and/or [[romance (love)|romantic desire]] (''[[eros (concept)|eros]]''), and [[Kenosis|self-emptying]] or divine love (''[[agape]]'').<ref>C.S. Lewis, ''[[The Four Loves]]'', 1960.</ref>
 
In terms of interpersonal attraction, four forms of love have traditionally been distinguished, based on ancient Greek precedent: the love of kinship or [[familial love|familiarity]] (in [[Ancient Greek|Greek]], ''[[storge]]''), the love of [[friendship]] (''[[philia]]''), the love of sexual and/or [[romance (love)|romantic desire]] (''[[eros (concept)|eros]]''), and [[Kenosis|self-emptying]] or divine love (''[[agape]]'').<ref>C.S. Lewis, ''[[The Four Loves]]'', 1960.</ref>
